TI Classification of Aerosols in an Urban Environment on the Basis of
   Optical Measurements
SO AEROSOL AND AIR QUALITY RESEARCH
LA English
DT Article
DE Aerosol; AERONET; Classification; AOD; SSA; DAE
ID SIZE DISTRIBUTION FUNCTION; INDO-GANGETIC PLAINS; ANGSTROM EXPONENT;
   SOURCE APPORTIONMENT; PARTICULATE MATTER; REFRACTIVE-INDEX; SATELLITE
   DATA; BLACK CARBON; AERONET; MODIS
AB The present study investigates various types of aerosol in the Lahore city of Pakistan using Aerosol Robotic Network (AERONET) data over a six year period from 2007 to 2012. Aerosol optical depths (AODs) observed was in the range 0.2-1.12. An analysis of seasonal variations in AOD has indicated that the highest AOD values occurred in summer and the lowest in winter. The urban aerosols of the study area were classified on the basis of optical parameters such as AOD, Extinction Angstrom Exponent (EAE), Absorption Angstrom Exponent (AAE), Single Scattering Albedo (SSA), Asymmetry Parameter (ASY) and Refractive Index (RI). The AAE values were in the range from 0.25 to 3.2. Real Refractive Index (RRI) and Imaginary part of the Refractive Index (IRI) values were in the range from 1.5 to 1.6 and 0 to 0.005 respectively. The major contributions to the atmospheric aerosols over Lahore were from urban industrial emissions, fossil fuel burning and road/soil dust. Higher RRI values reflected larger re-suspended road dust particles and long-range transported particles, while lower values reflected increased anthropogenic absorbing carbonaceous aerosols over the area. The AERONET retrieved SSA (0.80-0.89) and ASY (0.70-0.83) values suggested a predominance of urban industrial, vehicular and dust aerosols over Lahore. The Derivative of Angstrom Exponent (DAE) was derived at a wavelength of 500 nm and was found to indicate a predominance of fine aerosols across all seasons, particularly during summer and autumn seasons. Back-trajectory analyses using the Hybrid Single Particle Lagrangian Integrated Trajectory (HYSPLIT) model revealed that the major air masses over Lahore originated from India, Iran and Afghanistan.

TI Identification of HLA Class I Misreads/Dropouts Using Serological
   Typing, in Comparison with DNA-based Typing
SO IRANIAN JOURNAL OF ALLERGY ASTHMA AND IMMUNOLOGY
LA English
DT Article
DE Ambiguous antigens; Complement dependent lymphocytotoxicity (CDC); DNA
   based HLA typing; Human leukocyte antigen typing; Sequence specific
   primers (SSP)
ID MARROW
AB Serology and DNA techniques are employed for Human Leukocyte Antigen (HLA) typing in different transplant centers. Results may not always correlate well and may need retyping with different technique. All the patients (with aplastic anemia, thalassemia, and immunodeficiency) and their donors, requiring HLA typing for bone marrow transplant were enrolled in the study. Serological HLA typing was done by complement-dependent lymphocytotoxicity while DNA-based typing was done with sequence specific primers (SSP). Serology identified 167 HLA A and 165 HLA B antigens while SSP in same samples identified 181 HLA A and 184 HLA B alleles. A11 and B51 were the commonest antigens/alleles by both methods.
   There were a total of 21 misreads and 32 dropouts on serology, for both HLA A and B loci with HLA A32, B52 and B61 being the most ambiguous antigens.
   Inherent limitations of serological techniques warrant careful interpretation or use of DNA-based methods for resolution of ambiguous typing.
C1 [Tipu, Hamid Nawaz; Bashir, Muhammad Mukarram; Noman, Muhammad] Armed Forces Inst Pathol, Dept Immunol, Rawalpindi, Pakistan.
RP Tipu, HN (reprint author), Armed Forces Inst Pathol, Dept Immunol, Rawalpindi, Pakistan.

   Middelton Derek, 2005, Iran J Allergy Asthma Immunol, V4, P53
   Mishra M. N., 2004, International Journal of Human Genetics, V4, P151

TI Formulation and in vitro evaluation of carbopol 934-based modified
   clotrimazole gel for topical application
SO ANAIS DA ACADEMIA BRASILEIRA DE CIENCIAS
LA English
DT Article
DE Central composite design; clotrimazole; permeability enhancer; topical
   gel
ID PENETRATION ENHANCERS; STRATUM-CORNEUM; ALMOND OIL; DELIVERY; SKIN
AB The aim of present study was to enhance topical permeation of clotrimazole gel preparation by using various permeability enhancers such as coconut oil, pistachio oil and sodium lauryl sulphate (SLS). Clotrimazole gel preparations were prepared and optimized by using three factor, five level central composite design. A second-order polynomial equation was generated in order to estimate the effect of independent variables i.e. coconut oil (X-1), pistachio oil (X-2) and sodium lauryl sulphate (X-3) at various dependent variables i.e. flux (Y-1), lag time (Y-2), diffusion coefficient (Y-3), permeability coefficient (Y-4), and input rate (Y-5) of clotrimazole gel formulations. Ex vivo skin permeation study was performed through rat skin by using modified Franz diffusion cell system. Optimized formulation F8 exhibited highest flux 2.17 mu g/cm(2)/min, permeability coefficient 0.0019 cm/min and input rate 1.543 mu g/cm(2)/min, along with moderate lag time 77.27 min and diffusion coefficient 0.063 cm(2)/min, which is further supported by anti-fungal activity that exhibited more prominent zone of inhibition against Candida albicans, Aspergillus niger and Mucor. Thus, it can be concluded that permeation of clotrimazole gel was enhanced by various combination of coconut oil, pistachio oil and sodium lauryl sulphate but optimized formulation F8 containing 0.4 ml pistachio oil, 0.8 ml coconut oil and 0.04 g of SLS exhibited more pronounced and promising effect through rat skin.
C1 [Ubaid, Muhammad; Ilyas, Sadaf; Khan, Muhammad Z. U.; Kanwal, Zainab G.; Nawaz, Ahmad; Shah, Amna; Murtaza, Ghulam] COMSATS Inst Informat Technol, Dept Pharm, Abbottabad 22060, Pakistan.
   [Mir, Sadullah; Khan, Abida K.; Rashid, Rehana] COMSATS Inst Informat Technol, Dept Chem, Abbottabad 22060, Pakistan.
RP Murtaza, G (reprint author), COMSATS Inst Informat Technol, Dept Pharm, Abbottabad 22060, Pakistan.

TI RESPONSES OF NILI-RAVI BUFFALO AGAINST AFLATOXIN B1 WITH AND WITHOUT
   TOXIN ADSORBENTS
SO BUFFALO BULLETIN
LA English
DT Article
DE activated charcoal; aflatoxin B1; buffalo; glucomannan; HSCAS
ID DIETARY AFLATOXIN; FEED; BROILERS; MILK
AB The objective of study was to find feed intake, haematological and serum biochemical responses of Nili-Ravi buffalo against aflatoxin B1 (AFB1) and to determine the comparative efficacy of three different toxin adsorbents against AFB1. Twenty five Nili-Ravi buffaloes were selected from herd and divided into five groups for a period of 21 days to receive no aflatoxin B1 (AFB1) diet, diet contaminated with AFB1, diet contaminated with AFB1 with the addition of three different toxin adsorbents (glucomannan, hydrated sodium calcium aluminosilicate or HSCAS and activated charcoal) at inclusion level of 0.2% of feed. AFB1 was incorporated into feed at inclusion level of 500 ppb per animal per day.
   Results indicated that average daily feed intake of AFB1 treated buffaloes significantly reduced (P<0.05) compared to control. Serum levels of total bilirubin, alkaline phosphatase (ALP), alanine aminotransferase (ALT), aspartate aminotransferase (AST) and creatinine were significantly increased (P<0.05) but change in blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels was nonsignificant (P>0.05) due to AFB1. In haematology total erythrocytes count (TEC), total leukocytes count (TLC), haemoglobin concentration (HGB), haematocrit levels (HCT), mean corpuscular haemoglobin (MCH) and mean corpuscular haemoglobin concentration (MCHC) levels were decreased significantly (P<0.05) in AFB1 group on 14 and 21 days of experiment. Among all three toxin adsorbents 0.2% glucomannan significantly (P<0.05) improved the feed intake levels of buffaloes and also significantly (P<0.05) minimized the AFB1 induced adverse effects on haematology and serum biochemistry but was unable to totally ameliorate its effect.
C1 [Akhtar, Raheela; Sardar, Muqadas] Univ Vet & Anim Sci, Fac Vet Sci, Dept Pathol, Lahore, Pakistan.
   [Saima] Univ Vet & Anim Sci, Fac Vet Sci, Dept Anim Nutr, Lahore, Pakistan.
   [Yaqub, Tahir] Univ Vet & Anim Sci, Qual Operat Lab, Lahore, Pakistan.
